metadata.case_name: Returned Candidate from Farber Constituency v. Election Petitioner

facts.text: Appellant was a candidate in General Elections 1954 for Legislative Assembly of Patiala and East Punjab States Union (PEPSU) from Farber Constituency, secured largest number of votes, declared duly elected.
Result notified in Official Gazette on February 27, 1954.
Return of election expenses published in Official Gazette on May 2, 1954.
Rule 119(a) prescribes election petition against returned candidate to be presented not later than 14 days from publication of return of election expenses under Rule 113.
Last date for filing petition was May 16, 1954, which was a Sunday, and May 17, 1954 was a public holiday.
First respondent filed election petition on May 18, 1954 under s.81 Representation of the People Act 1951, alleging corrupt and illegal practices by appellant and agents, with particulars.
Petition stated offices closed on 16th and 17th May, so within limitation.
Election Commission ordered: petition filed 18-5-1954, but for holidays on 16-5 and 17-5 would be time-barred, admit.
Appellant filed written statement denying allegations, contended petition not presented within time under Rule 119(a).
Election Tribunal (Bhatinda) overruled time-bar plea applying Rule 26 Election Rules and s.10 General Clauses Act 1897.
Tribunal held on merits that appellant employed 25 persons in addition to allowed under Rule 118 and Schedule VI for payment in connection with election, committing corrupt practice u/s 123(7).
25 persons were paid employees of appellant (former ruler of Faridkot), in service long before election, not specially engaged, no extra allowances paid.
Tribunal declared election void u/s 100(2)(b), appellant disqualified u/ss 140(1)(a) and 140(2).
Evidence showed 25 persons took part in election campaign apart from polling agent duties, work done in morning or evening out of office hours.
Appellant retains large staff of subordinates from time as ruler of Faridkot.

legal_issues.text: Whether election petition presented within time under Rule 119(a), applying s.10 General Clauses Act to 'not later than fourteen days'.
Whether appellant contravened Rule 118 by employing 25 regular staff members for payment in connection with election, constituting corrupt practice u/s 123(7).

petitioner_arguments.text: Election petition not presented within time under Rule 119(a) as 'not later than fourteen days' is peremptory, differs from 'within a prescribed period' in s.10 General Clauses Act; Rule uses different phrasing from other rules like Rule 123.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 119(a); s.10 General Clauses Act; proviso to s.37 Representation of the People Act

petitioner_arguments.text: No contravention of Rule 118 as employees were regular long-term staff, not specially/ad hoc employed for election; no extra payment; casual work in addition to normal duties not 'employed for payment in connection with election'.

respondent_arguments.text: Petition within time as last days were holidays, covered by s.10 General Clauses Act via Rule 26.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.10 General Clauses Act; Rule 26 Election Rules

respondent_arguments.text: Rule 118 violated as 25 paid employees of appellant employed in connection with election, exceeding Schedule VI limit; regular employment suffices if used for election.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 118, s.123(7) Representation of the People Act; Hartlepools Case; Amritsar Case; Farrukhabad Case

court_reasoning.text: s.10 General Clauses Act applies as Rule 119(a) prescribes a period of 14 days ('not later than' same as 'within'); expires on holiday, done next open day valid; heading 'Time within which' confirms; s.81 RPA uses 'within such time as prescribed'.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Not later than fourteen days' means the same as 'within fourteen days'; no distinction.

court_reasoning.text: Proviso to s.37 RPA does not exclude s.10 GCA generally; Rule 26 applies GCA to rules.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Beneficent s.10 GCA not cut down on unsubstantial grounds.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 118 requires employment in connection with election for payment; not limited to ad hoc/special employment, but regular staff doing casual/additional election work (off normal duties) not covered; must be substantially whole-time election work, superseding normal work.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Payment must be for election employment; casual extra work not.

court_reasoning.text: No finding by Tribunal that 25 staff relieved of normal work for election; evidence shows work out of office hours/additional; respondent failed to prove, burden on him.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal misappreciated legal position; no requisite finding.

holdings.text: Election petition filed on May 18, 1954 in time under Rule 119(a) read with s.10 General Clauses Act.
No contravention of Rule 118; regular staff doing additional casual election work not 'employed for payment in connection with election'.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sirdar Gurdyal Singh v. Rajah of Faridkote
precedents_cited.relevance: Judicial recognition of Faridkot as independent state pre-merger in PEPSU.
Regular secretary not election agent unless duties include; business clerks on election work may require salary return.
Doubt on Phillimore J's observations in Hartlepools.
Employees put on election work wages should be shown; limited authority.
Salaries of employees working exclusively on election shown in return.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs election petitions, corrupt practices, disqualification, voiding elections; time limits via rules.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act, 1897
statutes_cited.relevance: If last day of prescribed period is holiday, act done next open day in time; applied via Rule 26.

statutes_cited.name: Conduct of Elections Rules (under RPA)
statutes_cited.relevance: Time for petitions; limit on paid employees; GCA applicability.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Election Tribunal order set aside; election petition dismissed as no contravention of Rule 118 proved despite petition being in time.

key_quotes.text: Broadly stated, the object of the section is to enable a person to do what he could have done on a holiday, on the next working day.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose and application of s.10 General Clauses Act.

key_quotes.text: Rule 118 does not require that the person engaged by a candidate to work in the election should have been specially employed for the purpose of the election. It is sufficient... that person is employed in connection with the election.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key construction of Rule 118 on employment.

key_quotes.text: But if, on the other hand, he takes them out of their normal work and puts them on whole-time or substantially whole-time work in connection with the election, that would amount to converting their general employment into one in connection with the election.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes casual vs substantial election employment.
